title: Lesson Indian Removal
description: A santized version of the indian removal made for H2 English/Cambridge

items.content:
You have used the videos provided in this lesson to practise with listening.

You have a better understanding of the things done to the Native Americans during their Removal period.

Welcome to this lesson about "The Indian Removal"

First, Watch the clip I made to tell you something about what The Indian Removal is, and why it is important to learn about this subject.

For the rest of the exercise you are going to take a look at clips from a youtube video made by Knowing Better. He recently made a video about this subject.

But before you do that, Read "Who is Knowing Better?"

Knowing Better is a youtuber who mostly makes video's about political and historical subjects in the United States. Other subject he discussed are neoslavery, The Oil industry, The Sigarette industry, but also religious groups and even some films and books. But as an overal theme, general misconceptions are a go-to theme.

Usually his video's are quite serious, but he also adds jokes, innuendos, personas or parodies to make the video's more entertaining while still remaining educative.

He used be in the militairy and was deployed to Iraq, after his service was over, he became a History teacher, but now he makes youtube video's fulltime. He calls himself a political moderate, which means that he doesn't lean right or left, and usually has fairly calm views about things.
Knowing Better usually talks very fast, so if you can't follow it because he is going to fast, you can set the video speed to 0.75. Although, it makes the sound a bit raspy.
Have a look at "What do you know?" to get an idea about the subject beforehand.

These questions are to test the knowledge you already have off the subject.

If you don't know, that's perfectly fine!

prompt.body:
What do you know about the united states during the 19th Century (The Wild West ~1840-1912, The US Civil War 1861-1865)

~ Think about stories, films or articles about these two periods.

content.body: I have no clue! (0)
I have seen a few movies or series about it! (1)
I have spent some time researching it! (2)
I am confident I know a lot about it! (3)

prompt.body: Have you heard about the term "Manifest Destiny"?

content.body: What, what now? (0)
I have heard of it! (1)
I think I know what it is! (2)
I know what is is! (3)

prompt.body: Accourding to your knowledge about native Americans, from nothing at all to a lot, how much do you think you know?

content.body: I haven't got a single clue (0)
I know a little bit (1)
I know some things (2)
I know a lot about it (3)

prompt.body: Have you heard of "The Indian Removal act"?

content.body: Never heard of it! (0)
I have heard of it! (1)
I know in broad terms what it means! (2)
I know exactly what it means! (3)

items.content: First, go to "Introduction to the video"

Add up all the numbers behind the answers you gave, and go to that part.

So, if you had 2 1 0 3, That's 6 in total, so you go to score 5-8
Have a look at "Introduction to the video"
Listen and watch the introduction of the video, this is from 0:00 to 2:05

For all videos you should look up words that you don't know!

I also recommend you turn on the subtitles for Knowing Better's video,
Now, go to Lesson 1 part 1 and go to the subheading in which you scored

Based on your score from the "What do you know?" questions, go to sub-section in which you scored.

There, watch the explaination I made about the subject.

prompt.body: What was the main reason behind the colonization of North and South America?

content.body: To spread Christianity
To expand trading and production of certain crops
To explore unknown territories
To establish new political systems

prompt.body: Which colony was the first successful English settlement in North America?

content.body: Roanoke
Plymouth
Jamestown
Charleston

prompt.body: What was the primary crop that helped Jamestown become profitable?

content.body: Wheat
Tobacco
Corn
Potatoes

items.content: After answering the questions, go to "Causes and first steps of the Removal"

prompt.body: Which of the following is true about the English attempts at colonization in North America?

content.body: The second attempt was successful and founded Jamestown
The second attempt was unsuccessful and founded Roanoke
Both attempts failed due to unknown reasons
Both attempts were successful and founded prosperous colonies

prompt.body: What was one of the main reasons for colonization for England en France around the year 1600?

content.body: They wanted to make money off of it, like Spain was doing. By trading or growing crops.
They just wanted to expand their borders into new land.
France and England were tired of fighting each other, so they set their sights on something else.
Because they were looking for a fun adventure.

prompt.body: What was the main reason for European nations to start colonization in the late 16th century?

content.body: To expand trading and production of certain crops
To find a new homeland for their people
To conquer new territories for their kings
To spread Christianity to the natives

items.content: After answering the questions, go to "Causes and first steps of the Removal"

prompt.body: Why did so many native die after Columbus set foot on American shores?

content.body: Columbus and his men killed so many natives by attacking them with their new weapons; Guns.
After his arrival they started wars among themselves, and as a result many died.
He unintentionally spread diseases he carried to the Natives, who weren't used to those illnesses.
After Columbus arrived, no natives died more than they usually did.

prompt.body: How did the spread of diseases affect the Native American population after Columbus arrived in the Caribbean?

content.body: They were immune to the new diseases brought by the Europeans
They were able to quickly develop immunity to the new diseases
Many of them died from the diseases, as they had no prior exposure to them
They were able to avoid the diseases by staying away from the Europeans

prompt.body: Despite what, did the Jamestown colony survive?

content.body: Being attacked by Natives and Vikings.
A disease that killed many colonists.
Nothing, they were just having a blast.
Cold and Food shortage.

items.content: After answering the questions, go to "Causes and first steps of the Removal"

heading.content: Causes and first steps of the Removal Explained

items.content: Watch the video from 8:06 - 13:30
Then answer these questions.

prompt.body: Why is the movie "Pocahontas" problematic for this subject?

content.body: Because it tells a version of a story that is untrue to what actually happened!
Because it's just a bad movie!
Pocahontas never actually existed and is a made up character for the Disney film!
Because it barely shows the native american side of the story.

prompt.body: Why did the Natives help the French during the French and Indian war?

content.body: Because they thought the French had a funny accent.
Because they were bribed by the French to help defeat the British colonists.
Because they saw the French as trading partners instead of people trying to invade their land.
We don't know the reason to this day.

prompt.body: Were the smallpox blankets ever used by British settlers to exterminate the Natives?

content.body: Yes, that's why about ninety percent of the population had died.
We don't know for sure, but the settlers certainly planned on using them.
No, they were never used and the settlers never planned on using them either.
There were blankets, but they weren't infected with smallpox, instead, the settlers wanted to help the Natives survive the winter.

items.content: Go to Lesson 1 part 2, and watch the video!

heading.content: Lesson 1 Part 2; Start of the Removal

items.content: Watch the video from 20:24 - 22:21
Then answer these questions.

prompt.body: Why did the southern states want the Natives gone?

content.body: They wanted to use the natural resources they were living on. Which they couldn't take, because there was a treaty in place.
They thought they were fine living there, but they also knew the Natives couldn't stay there.
They felt they were a threat to the American people that were also living in the area.
They didn't want them gone, the Natives wanted to go themselves.

prompt.body: Did Isaac McCoy know where he was attempting to relocate the Natives to?

content.body: He though it was a fruitful paradise, and wanted the best for the natives.
He knew it was a barren wasteland, but never visited himself.
He knew it was a wasteland, which he saw for himself when he had visited.
He didn't know where he was sending them to, but though the Natives would be alright.

prompt.body: Did the U.S. government have any plans to settle the Luisiana territory?

content.body: They wanted to go on after the Mississippi, and knew they would have to remove the Natives even further.
No, they were content with the land they had east of the Mississippi. And everyone lived happily ever after.
Originally The saw the Mississippi as a natural border, and didn't have any plans to settle there so they wanted to relocate the Natives there, and than leave it at that.
They intentionally went on settling west of the Mississippi, and destroyed every native village they came across.

items.content: This is the end of Lesson 1, Raise your hand if you have reached this part, and continue with the Homework assignment!

Now you know a little bit about the subject.

As a homework exercise you are going to write a letter.

Pretend that I (Mr. Smit) am the U.S. Government, and you are a Native American.

Use 50-100 words (you can make it longer if you really want to) to express why you feel terrible about the idea that you would have to move to an unknown place.

Send me a e-mail, which is a digital place holder for the letter or send me a document, with the letter in it. The deadline is tuesday 23:59.

heading.content: Lesson 2 Part 1; During and after Removal

items.content: You have seen and heard about what the White Americans did to the Native Americans. But lets have a look at how the situation currently is.
Watch the video from 1:10:38 to 14:53

prompt.body: Why do more White People live on the reservations than Native Americans?

content.body: Because the Natives are currently very inclusive, and they like the company of white americans nearby.
It's not true, there aren't any white people living on reservations.
Because white americans are the rightful owners of the land, and the Natives are holding it hostage.
Because the Natives were only allowed to recieve so much land, and any more was sold to white people on the open market.

prompt.body: How much land could heads of households get when the land was suited for grazing only?

content.body: 160 acres
40 acres and a mule
320 acres
80 acres and a mule

prompt.body: Why are there almost no grocery stores on the reservation to this day?

content.body: Because companies don't want to build a store on a piece of land they can't own.
Because the Natives are stopping any attempts at companies from building stores.
Because the Companies don't think it will be profitable.
Because they don't like the climate, and it's pretty much in the middle of nowhere.

items.content: First, we are going to play a kahoot!
Then fill in these two Google forms!

The Indian Removal - A process in which the Native Americans were forced out of the areas where they had lived for thousands of years (In most cases) by british settlers who arrived in the American continent only one-hundred and fifty years earlier
Neoslavery - Slavery that still exists today, but in his video he talked about the unequal treatment of former slaves by the south.
General misconception - Something that most people think is true (or false), but actually isn't (or is)
Go-to - Something that is often chosen for regular and reliable (trustworthy) result
Innuendo - Something that is implied, usually by gestures or specific wording, but not directly said.
Persona - A role or character that is adopted by the author. Usually as an act.
Raspy - a bit harsh, like it's going through a grate
